newsitem.title: CHINA: Yuan ends up at a 10-week high against US dollar.
newsitem.headline: Yuan ends up at a 10-week high against US dollar.

text.p: The Chinese yuan closed up at a 10-week high close of 8.2938 on Tuesday from Monday's 8.2955 against the U.S. dollar in Shanghai due to speculative buying in the last few minutes of trading, traders said.
It was the highest close since February 18 when the yuan ended at 8.2926.
The weighted average price on Monday was 8.2949.
Dealers said that despite the speculation, the yuan's rise on Tuesday strengthened the pro-yuan sentiment which has prevail ed in the market in the recent weeks.
The yuan opened much higher at an intraday high of 8.2860 and fell quickly to hit a low of 8.2950 early in trading.
It then moved around 8.2945 for most of the session before speculative buying set in to push it up again.
Trading was less active than Monday with most business done at 8.2945, traders said.
One dealer said the high opening was possibly due to one transaction but it had a positive impact on the yuan's upward trend throughout the rest of the session.
"The opening boosted confidence even though the yuan could not stand firm at such a high level," he said.
"This was reflected in the fact that most of today's business was done above the key 8.2950 level," he added.
A second dealer said reduced intervention by the People's Bank of China was another factor for the yuan's rise today.
"Recently, the central bank has done little to depress the yuan, which has made yuan buying active," he said.
Dealers said they expected the yuan to move between 8.2940 and 8.2950 on Wednesday.
The yuan ended up at 6.5360 from 6.5410 against 100 Japanese yen and up at an intraday high of 1.0698 from 1.0713 against the Hong Kong dollar. -- Shanghai newsroom (86-21) 6279-7004
